text: Draft at the brewery. Clear orange copper. Aroma is funky with notes of Brett and apples. Sweet, flavors of wood, brown sugar, cider, Brett. Light-bodied, flat.

Draught at Cantillon Brewery, Brussels. Clear golden with no head. Sweetish aroma with notes of yeasts, sugar, candy and rum, perfumed. Sweet flavor with notes of candy, sugar, rum and apple juice. Flat, medium-bodied.
Draft - Raisin and green apple or tea leaf notes. Clear copper gold. Bitter and some tea leaf with a long bitterness in the finish. The weird tea bitterness is dominant for me.
At the brewery.  Smooth sweetish and round. Sourish beginning, round and smooth with not too much sweetness. Long sourish-sweet aftertaste, nice.

Draught. Pours dark amber/light brown in clour, quite clear with huge white head. Aroma is sweet, caramel and sugar with tart note. In taste sour at first then it is sweetened with sugary caramel notes, not cloying or tiring. Medium body, fizzy carbonation, sweet finish. One of the best faro I tried.
Glass @ the brewery in 2011. Amber, a bit hazy, with no head. Aroma is a bit sour, with distinct funky, wild notes. Taste is sweet, a bit sour, with wooden aftertaste (from barrel). Very good.
Tap @ Moeder Lambic. Clear golden body with a small white head. Tart, sugary sweetness. It has the Cantillon tartness. Faro isnt my style.

Tap at Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Clear dark golden with quite big and lasting white head. Lots of funky grains, sweet lemon, typical Cantillon wood and twigs, hay, peach, sweet white grapes, bitter herbs. Light sour, under medium bitter and almost medium sweetness tying it all together. Medium bodied with very soft carbonation. Maybe a bit too bitter, but a nice beer and a great faro.

At Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Clear golden with thin white head. Grain, hay, tea, grapes, sugar syrup, young green, resiny. Light sour over medium sweet sugary base, light minerallike saltiness. Balances out really well. Medium body, unnoticeable carbonation. Very drinkable, very nice.
Hazy golden with medium white head. Aroma is caramel and citrus. Taste is sweet with notes of citrus

On tap at Chez Moeder. It pours hazy amber with a bubbly off white head. The aroma is both sour and sweet with malty notes. Quite sweet flavor with the classic Cantillon sour kick. Malty backbone. Nice one.
Draft at chez moeder. Aroma of caramel and brown sugar with yeast notes. The flavours is sweet and slightly Sour. The body is medium and the texture is juicy.

Glass at the brewery. Poured pale, bit of foam. Still usual Cantillon autumn funk aroma. Taste for this one was sweeter and still feeling light. Sourness there but not too pronounced, more going on in the funk department.

Glass @ the brewery, from a jug (presumably straight from a barrel). Copper color, hazy. No head. Aromas: sourish, funky. Retronasal its sour, yoghurt/lactic, some funk and wood. Flavor is moderate sweet, moderate sour. Light bodied. Finishes slightly dry, with some grain and a hint of bitterness. I liked it.

Tap at moeder lambic. Pours a hazy orange with a lasting bubbly white head. Aroma of vinegar, soy sauce, citrus, caramel, melon. Taste is of vinegar, caramel, dried fruits, butterscotch. Soft oily, slightly sticky mouthfeel, little to no carbonation.

Nov 2015 - Unknown dispense, poured from a ceramic jug at the Cantillon brewery. Hazy dark orange, still, small bubbly white head. Aroma is sweet syrups, biscuits, light sourness. Body is medium, smooth, light carbonation. Taste is light vanilla, red berries, smooth, apple, very light sourness. Not too sweet, which is often what lets the style down.
From notes on 9/15/15. On Cask at Moeder Lambic. Poured a light color, almost like a pilsner. Big sweet taste. Hints of apricot maybe? Very good.
UPDATED: MAY 6, 2016 Sweeter than any other Cantillon ive had and among the most interesting. Brownish in color and very drinkable.

From tap at Moeder Lambic Fontainas, Brussel. Aroma of tart fruits, ripe citrus, some sugary notes, some malt and caramel. Flavour is moderate sweet and moderate sour. Body is medium. Never thought Id say it, but this is a decent Faro.
Smell of blue cheese, mold, light barnyard, citrusy, a bit burned sugar. Taste is overly sweet, a bit of citrus, and clear blue cheese. Not really my favourite.

Cask At moeder. Pours hazy orange with faomy white head. Aroma tart, funk, quite sweet, sugary. Taste is quite un complex, with a very sweet ending. The huge amount of sugar, blocks the real good things beneath.

Different from all the other Catntillion flavors. Very good but different. Tart with toffee sweetness. Had many times but odd. Still great. Pours dark garnet with no real head. Predominantly sweetness with the tart that did start to balance it out. Finished leather and earthy.

Pours hazy golden with medium white head that has rather large bubbles to her. Notes of sour funk, malt, sugar and cream. Medium bodied. Too sweet for me but was still enjoyable considering the producer.

From Cask at Chez Moeder Lambic Saint-Gilles. Light hazy dark orange color with small bubbly head that quickly disappears. Aroma is malty, light fruity, apples, caramel, sugar, medicine. Sweet taste like aroma. Light oily body with flat carbonation.

similar tart, lemony nose, slightly darker gold with noticable candy sugar sweetness that well balances the sharpness making it oh so easy to knock back
Draught at Chez Moeder Lambic, Brussels, Belgium. Clear chestnut, low head. Cidry, with rummy and sirupy notes. Medium bodied, low carbonation. Semi sweet, medium acidity.

Preparato al the dome con zucchero candito.
Ambrata senza schiuma.
Lambic piatto addolcito.  ---Rated via Beer Buddy for Mi4i

Cask @ Moeder Lambic Fontainas, Brussels. Pours orange with a large, large-bubbled, white head. Aroma is somewhat sour, fermented apple, sugared soda. Fermented fruit. Taste is appleskin, light sweetness, not very sour.
2010. At the brewery from a jug. Pours Orange yellow hazy with almost no head. Aroma oak, malts, tasty. Not Bad.
Pours clear golden. Aroma is sherry, sour. Taste is milder than i expected. Fruity, slightly sour.
On cask at Moeder Lambic. Poured light hazy amber orange with white head. Aroma sweet little malt funk. Light carb med bod. Very sweet taste, sweetened tea, lemon, orange.

Hazy orangeish pale brown colour with a mediumsized beige creamy head. aroma is sugar meeting sour wooden notes and some mild caramel and raisins. Flavour is dry wood with some sweet syrupy notes as well as some quite earthy notes.
Cask at chez moeder lambic. Pours deep amber, nose is light funk, sugary, taste is sweet, light funk, fruity.

Cantillon Faro 5% at Moeder Lambic pours an orange brown with a foamy beige head. Musty fruity wine and sweetness in the nose. Tart but sweet with some acidity and sourness. Wonderful.  Best Faro Ive ever had, then again this is also the only authentic one Ive had.

Lasting white head. Almiost clear amber color. Strange beer / acidic wine aroma with fresh fruit acid. Sweet taste with a harsh astringen bitterness and small acidity in the taste. This is a strange beer.

(On cask at Moeder Lambic Fontainas, July 24 2015) Pours very murky burnt orange with bubbly lingering white cask head. Aroma has a real sweet undercurrent of caramel and a bit of dates and figs, musty with light Brett, odd overtone of a chlorine pool building. Flavour is sweet candy sugar, tart acidity and a bit of sourness underneath, kind of fruity with fig, orange and a little lemon. Bit of a soft apple cider character going on. Bretty funk is present if not super strong, as is the wood - leather and light barnyard. Medium cask mouthfeel with no carb. Aftertaste is tart and a little astringent. Faro is probably not my style but in fairness this is a pretty good brew and if I werent surrounded by unsweetened lambics Im sure Id be happy to drink another.
On cask at Morder Lambic, Brussels . Orangel murky body. Sweet yesay and sour citrus lemonand orange . Smooth palate fromantic the cadk. Nice beer.
Another great brew. Im assuming Im smelling faro...Lots of grain and sweet and malts with a nice sour and funky and kick. Great.

Tap at Moeder Lambic. Hazy orange color, medium white head. Aroma is sweet citrus, funky, light barnyard note, leather. Taste is light sour and sweet. In the past i only drink Faro from lindemans and thinking that Faro is very sweet, broken lambic. Cantillon version is different, nice balanced sour and sweet taste, still have that wild lambic character. Very good and refreshing beer.

Keg at The 24th Weekend Of Spontaneous Fermentation. I have (had) a really poor opinion of Faro as a style having not really tried many of them. I thought if anyone could make the style work then its Cantillon. The idea of adding sugar to Lambic is criminal. This wasnt totally awful though. The sweetness is incorporated quite well. Funky lemon sourness. With a clear barnyard funk. Decent.
Tap @ Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas, Brussels 13/5-15. Fruity with apples/pear, sweet.

Cask au Moeder Fontainas. Couleur orangée trouble, mousse beige aérienne. Arôme boisé, levure sauvage, fruits mûrs. Goût boisé, acidité faible, un peu sucré, amertume légère en fin de bouche. Absence de carbonatation, corps moyen-faible.
On draft at Moeder Lambic with an American friend! Sweet, grain, brown sugar, little citrus. A waste of lambic really, since it's soo sweet almost all complexity is gone.
UPDATED: JUN 8, 2015 Tap @ Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas, Brussels 150513. Really fruity and light acidic, bretty, sweet, flat, medium body with an oily texture. The finish is fruity and sweet.

Draft pour. Pours a somewhat hazy, dark copper color with a white head. The aroma is sweet and sugary with some grassy notes. The taste is mostly sweet and just a touch sour. Medium body and lower carbonation.
[Ölresa Bryssel med Wihlan 2015] @ Moeder Lambic. Fantastisk balans i smaken och kroppen !
Draft at Moeder - pours orange/yellow. Nose and taste is sweet, sour, lemon zest.

On tap At Moder Lambic. Cloudy yellow pour with a white head. Mild sour aromas. Really sweet, almost desert wine or sugary sweet, with mild sour backbeats. Some malts and grains in the distance. Average body and mouthfeel.

Pour at Cantillon. Clear golden light brown color with no head. Very sweet, sugar is quite notable, with a touch of tartness. No carbonation. Thin. Worst beer I had during my visit to Cantillon. But its probably more the style than it is the actual beer.
Tap. Hazy golden with white head. Aroma of lambic funk, earth, apples. Taste has a lot of sharp green apple with some earthy funk. Little sweet but not overly so, slightly acidic as well.

On cask @ Moeder Lambic Fontainas, Brussels - BE. Color: hazy amber beer with no carbonation and small white foam. Smell: sour nose and small caramel finish. Candy. Taste: sweet sensation, caramel and candy. Fruity notes. Candied fruit finish. Aftertaste: sweet sour sensation.

Moeder lambic.
Appearance: Not too nice brown, hazy.
Aroma: skunky sour, Strong old fruit.
Taste: Bitter, no bubbles, old. Flat and burned finish, bitter.

Pours golden. No head. Flat. Aroma of brown sugar, wet dog. Slightly mouldy taste. Sweet and sour.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Moeder Lambic. Sour orange juice aroma with a some herbal hops and faint celery. Hazy bronze under a bubbly white collar. Sweet and sour flavour thats curiously delicate and finishes quite clean, except for a lingering, tannic bitterness. Very little goaty character. Medium body, low carbonation, slightly mouth puckering and tingly.
Un peu plus de complexité et de rondeur que le Lambic, un faro ultra raffraîchissant et harmonieux.
Cask at Moeder Lambic, 5th March 15. Fairly cloudy, aroma is sweet funk, the taste is sour, tempered down and this drinks easily, sour farmyard notes, not overly astringent. Nice
Amber color with little foam. The smell is weirdly like old sweetness. The taste is sweet but not sugary. No carbonation with little to no sourness. Not as convincing as hoped.

On tap at Moeder Lambic. Dark golden color with white head. Aroma is sweet, balsamico, a bit of subtle funk. Taste is fruity-sweet, not really sour, the Lambiv character gets lost. Not very complex but this is a lovely Faro!

Silky smooth dark amber pour, flattish. aroma of Cassonade Graeffe aka cured beetroot sugar stored in an open oak container, sprinkled with the mild balsamics of ripe lemons. Drinks likes only slightly funky lemonade, slick not sticky. - My take on the FAQ No. 1 regarding this style: Faro represents a historical chapter in lambieks demotic survival during the dark 70s-90s ages of oude geuzes steady decline and could still be considered the broad publics preferred imbibing state...

January 23, 2015. On tap at Moeder Lambic Fontainas. 
Cloudy orange with a large white head. Aroma is sweet caramel, some fruity tartness with citrus and green apples, light funky. Taste ss sweet caramel with some fruity and funky notes, dry finish with oak and earth.

Cask at Moeder Lambic Fontinas. Pours a nice hazy amber with a reasonable foamy white head. Funky aroma. Citrusy sourness but with an overwhelming caramel sugary flavour (stronger sweetness than I have had before in a Faro). Couldnt help wonder why on earth you would add that sweetness to a delicious Cantillon lambic...

Cask at Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Pours lightly cloudy amber with a large, rocky off-white head, long retention with good lacing. Aroma is earthy and cellar malt, cherry notes, oak, barnyard yeast. Flavor is sweet and tart fruits and cereal malt, earthy and barnyard yeast notes with a dry finish. Light body and medium carbonation.

Cask during Brussels vacation. Murky dark golden with beige head. Aroma sweet, sugar, malt, light tart notes, ashtray, half-smoked cigarette. Taste has more ash, ashtray, sugar, tart notes, malt and more sugar.

Tap at Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas, Brussels. Poured a hazy medium amber with a big frothy white head. The aroma is rich sweet citrus rind, light spice. The flavour is moderate to strong sweet, light sour with a smooth sugary sour yeast palate and some lingering sourness in the finish. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. Lots of sweetness up front and the sourness is all there at the back of your throat. Very refreshing indeed.

Cerveza turbia de color naranja claro, cabeza espumosa pequeña.
Aroma a malta, caramelo y azúcar moreno.
Sabor dulce y amargo del cítrico, un final seco a madera, realmente buena.
Sickly sugary sweet with some sour aftertaste. Somewhat fruity, not my style. Cask at moeder lambic.

from cask at moeder lambic. poured a murky dark golden colour with a white head. lemons, green apple, kind of some, sweetness, caramel, sugar, wood, not my kind of style, why would you add sugar to a geuze....

Cask at Moeder Lambic Fontainas - Brussels. Pours cloudy orange-gold with a lasting, frothy white head. Light grassy nose, some rindy citrus, background funk. Medium to big sweet flavor, mild sour bite, a bit of that cloying faro greatness, some salt, light grass. Light to medium bodied with fine carbonation. Sweet finish with nips of leather, grass, sugar, cereal grains. Faro.
Draft at Moeder Lambic in Brussels. Big white head on a hazy light brownish amber pour. Sweet and malty nose. Sweet taste with a nice touch of funk. Cool.
Smell is barnyard funk. Taste is moderate sourness, apples and tangerine notes in there. A touch of citrus is evident here. quite a nice brew but after a Kriek it is not quite the same.
Cask @ Moeder Lambic. Clear light brown pour with a generous head. Light funk, brown sugar, hay and some herbal notes.

On tap at Moeder Fontainas. Pours a dark blond with creamy white head. Aroma is barnyard funk and candied apples. Taste is light rustic sourness, brett and candi sugar. A little harsh. I prefered Girardins faro.

(Cantillon Faro) 250 ml glass from tap at Moeder Lambic, Brussels, served into a tumbler.
Murky light orange colour on the body, small frothy head, more like just bubbles actually. Okay retention though.
Aroma of white grapes, sugars, some red fruits too.
Nice taste, sugars, fruits, quite sweet.
Medium thin body, low carbonation, very dry on the palate.
Enjoyable beer and very refreshing in spite of its sweetness.

Cask at Chez Moeder Saint-Gilles and poured into Cantillon lambic glass.

Pours a bronze/orange/red in color, bubbles on top, thin ring of foam. Nose is sweet sugars, light tartness. Flavor is more of the same, not all that complex, but enjoyable for what it is. Sweet, fruity, light oak, sugars. Light body, refreshing, dry finish.

A nice Faro that both my wife and I enjoyed a few pours of. Just easy-drinking, light, and refreshing. Good stuff.
On tap at brewery; cloudy amber color. Somewhat sweet and sour, with vinegar notes .. this one was not for me (didnt finish it).
Amber cloudy with medium white cap. Sweet with certain notes of bitterness.
Thanks to Kraddel. Shared at weekly tasting. Pours orange gold. Nose/taste of funky oak, lemon, light brown sugar and acidic caramel. Medium body.

Totally traditional faro as it was consumed in huge quantities in Brussels in the 19th century: young lambic with candi sugar added to enhance the drinkability, not bottled and only served from the cask. Tasted at Cantillon where it is sold to visitors. Cloudy amber colour, practically no head; complex funkiness of the Cantillon lambic, sour but softened by the sweetness of the candi sugar. Extremely old-fashioned and very thirst-quenching.

Cask @ Moeder Lambic, Fontaines. Pours light hazy golden with a small white head. Aroma is light sour, grapes, white sugar, some wood, dusty. Flavor is sourness, white sugar, white grapes, barnyards, wood, dust. Medium body, soft carbonation, light sour finish. 300714

Draft a Moeder Lambic wih Taylor and Kimberly. Pours murky bronze orang with big foam bubbles. Aroma is very nice classic cantillon funk with a coolaid sweetness. Taste is very sweet, low acidity, sugar water, hint if nice Gueuze funk, but the beer us sheen destroyed by the addition if sugar. It is a shame the brewery decided to ruin perfectly good Gueuze with sugar, blah.
Tap at Moeder. Darker than the gueuze. Woody, vinous notes on a sour backbone. Light sweetness.

Tap @ moederlambik . Pours hazy amber with an off white head. Aroma of lacto acid, vinegar, some sugar, stable, yogurt and bit of sweet balsamic. Taste of sweet vinegar, some sweet sugar notes, balsamic and some sweeter fruits. Overall a bit of a "Flemish" feel to it. Pretty okay faro mayn!

Z kija w Moeder Lambik, Bruksela. 
Piwo jest mętne o kolorze bursztynu i brudnej pomarańczy. W aromacie można wyczuć świeżość, karmel, kompot z rabarbaru i jabłek. Drewno. Smak piwa potwierdza słodki, łatwy w piciu lambik. Bardzo przyjemny. Wodnisty i mało gazowany.

Draught @ Moeder Lambic, Brussels. Pours murky amber with airy but stable white head. Clear vinous aroma, with subtle notes of fruit and hops. Bittter, hoppy onset, giving way to hefty vinous notes and touches of fruit and hops. Creamy mouthfeel. Vinous aftertaste with estery hints. Very good.
Pint at Ches moedeur, standard light barnyard cantillon with a molasses light sweetness in the background, minimal additional sweetness adds a layer of flavors, interesting

Tap. Hazy amber body with a small, white head. Aroma of barnyard, funk, yeast and brown sugar notes. Slightly sweet flavor that ends up dry and tart. Medium bodied oily texture and average carb. An excellent faro.
I am enjoying these faro, brews. Garnet colour, wonderful bubbles and lace. Sweet n sour slight vinegar. Some oak Chardonnay characteristics. Well done.
from Moeder Lambic Fontainas - hazy red-orange beer under a long lasting pale beige foam; red fruits and hints of vinegar; pretty sweet, medium-bodied, juicy red fruity finish with metallic notes

On tap, 25cL. @Moeder St Gilles, Brussels. An unclear orange beer with brown hues with almost no head. Poor persistence. Aroma is woody and smoky with an apple touch. Acid lactic. Wood and apple are easier to appreciate there than in the "pure" lambic version. First light sweet, then sharp sour note. In the middle and the end, heavy lasting sour. Good balance between sourness and sweetness. Sweetness doesnt hide, it always underlies sourness. Nice dance. Light body, sugar thin texture, flat carbonation, sour finish with a light sugar sweet background. Overall, I really enjoyed this Faro : more woody and fruity, nice soursweet taste. Yes!
Somewhat opaque darker yellow with bubbly white foam head. Bittersweet aroma and taste, you have to get used to this. Interesting mouth feel. (Brussels 201405)

Cask @ Moeder. Almost sweet, murky and thick. Honey and sugar mixed with apples, lemon and minimal funk. More true to style than other overly sweetened Faros Ive had. Goes down way too easy and great as in-between-lambic beer.

Cask at Moeder Lambic Fontainas, Brussels. Quite a dark shade of amber. One finger of head that recedes to a ring. Not getting much of anything, buttery caramel with a hint of fruit is all. It doesnt taste sugary sweet like some faros, which may be a plus for some people, but for me there was little to grab my attention. Very still, carb seems low. This slipped past a bit unnoticed.

Murky pour from a pitcher while touring Cantillon brewery with Joe. Very interesting to try, a bit sweet with a viscous, almost-thick presence in the small tasting glass. Farmhouse aromas with candi sugar, caramelized note on the finish. Nice to try this one.
Cask at moeder! Lovely color to a somewhat nice beer. the sweet flavored lambic is good but not amazing, probably mostly because of the style and not the maker or anything like that.
Cask at Moeder. Pours brownish orange with an off white head with big bubbles from the cask. Aroma is floral, ciders. Refreshing, easy to drink, with flavors follow nose, with some muscat grape.
Draught at Moeder Lambic. Sour taste with apple, earthy notes, honey, acidic notes, toast and ripe fruits. Sour finish with honey, apple and acidic notes. Excellent lambic.

Härlig och läskande samtidigt som man lätt tröttnas snabbt. Lite udda och man får inte direkt cantillonkänslan. Härlig sötma. Glaset tog slut oerhört snabbt. Delar med Hans och J Wallén på bryggeriet.

Cask @ Moeder Lambic Fontainas (Bruxelles). Hazy dark golden / amber with a medium fully disappearing white head and no lacing. Aroma is of subdued barnyard funk, brown sugar, oak and some fruits. Taste is slightly sweet with candi sugar, oak, light barnyard, acidic notes and some fruits here too. Light body. Low carbonation. Slightly acrid finish. Not a bad Faro.
On tap at moeder limbic. Pours out a hazy golden brown no head. Nose is funk grain and fruit notes. Taste is as the nose with a little pucker thickness and a great finish.

Bu à la pompe en 25Tcl, couleur ambrée et petite mousse, grosse attaque sur lacidité à la cantillon très citronneuse, mais le sucre candy casse parfaitement lacidité en fin de bouche et la rend très facile, un délice
Belle couleur, nez plutôt plaisant sur le fruit, acidité en bouche mais pas de trop. Finale sèche avec une pointe d'amertume.

Growler at home, THX Mathieu87.
APPPEARANCE: light clouded blond beer, no foam.
NOSE: alcohol, little fruity, hay, little sweet, horse blanket.
TASTE: sweet, sour, flat, wood.
One of the better Faros I had! Wasnt that sweet at all, nice and sour.

On tap at Chez Moeder Lambic in mid November. Muddy, deep golden body with a fluffy small white head. Wooden barrel nose. Mouth is sweet grapefruit juice with a cereal finish. Medium bodied and a dry tongue.

At the brewery. Clear dark gold pour, completely still. Aroma is very tame, only faint notes of Cantillon funk, very very light cheesy aromas. Taste is sweet, not overly done, cuts through the trademark Cantillon sourness in a pleasant way, interesting how the sweetness really brings out the woodiness in the beer, got some big bold oak flavor in this one. The beer is mild, probably just as acidic as any other Cantillon, but it certainly does not give you that impression. Palate is flat, finishes clean, semi-sweet. Quite enjoyable.

Cask at Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Pours cloudy golden with a short lasting white head. Aroma is sour, some sugar, funky and peach. Taste is moderate sweet and light to moderate sour. Medium body with soft carbonation.

Glass at brewery. Clear golden amber with no head. Aroma is slightly acidic and mildly sweet with some yeast funks. Taste is quite the same with bitter aftertaste. Thin to medium body with no carbonation and dry mouthfeel. Overall I liked it but miss some Co2 that I like so much in a beer. Felt more like a white wine somehow.

From tap at moeder lambic fontainas. Pours dark yellow with small head and low carbonation. Aroma is sour cream funk, sweet touch. Taste is only slightly sour, medium sweet, bitter notes. Good drinkable faro. Kind of entry gueuze for me.

Glass at Cantillon brewary after tour. Sweet from the casring sugar but still very sharp bitterness. No head or carbination due to open fermentation. Interesting and aquired taste. Has a almost prune apricot bite

On cask, pours darker blond, two finger loose white head. 

Smell wheaty, slightly tart

Taste sweet licorice, candy sugar, not that tart but pretty sweet.

Light body.

First of they style Ive tried, it is pretty interesting.

Draft @ Moeder Lambic, Brussels. Pours a hazy golden beer with a long lasting, bubbly white head on top. Aroma is sugary, oaky, no tartness and touches of banana. Flavor is medium sweet with yeasty and sugary components defintely there. Some slight woody touches in the short aftertaste. Decent session lambic, could probably drink this all day if it was sunny...

On cask at Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Finger and a half of frothy off-white head, incredibly hazy in clarity, almost cider-like in appearance, dark orange/brown in color. Apple and some light apricot, not as tart as other Cantillon offerings, can definitely sense its on the sweeter side. Sweeter, but still has a nice backing tartness, I get some lemon and a little apple cider vinegar. Light mouthfeel, though it has a little more body than their other offerings, light acidity, and a moderate finish. Much better than I expected, one of the best faros Ive had. Typically not a style I enjoy but this is quite drinkable.

Draught at Moeder Lambic Fontainas.
A smooth and sweet faro, drinkable with a taste of strawberries.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2014 20.04.2013, tap @ the brewery:
Rar lukt med preg av malt, humle, gras, sitrusskal, kalk, tre, bærskal. Mild lett sødmerik smak med preg av malt, humle, syregras, sukker, gras, bærskal. Middels bitterhet som set litt. Grei.

Cask at Moeder Lambic, 09/26/2013. Hazy copper pour, healthy frothy head, great retention. Aroma is mildly sweet, funky cereal malts, bread, lemon overtones. Taste is sweet cereal malts, mild barnyard funk, subtle bitterness to balance in the finish. Medium full body, creamy. Was nice to have this fresh, not bad at all.

Moeder draft. Slightly hazy orange color with a bubbly white head. Tart, sour aroma. Flavor starts sweet but then has a mineral bite at the finish. Not bad just odd but take that with a grain of salt since I think this is my second faro.

@ Cantillon. Pours hazy brownish amber with no head. Aroma of bread, hay, maybe light honey? Taste is funky sweet with lightly sour finish. Body is light and slick with very low carbonation.

From cask @ moeder lambic. Darker orange with carbonated looking med head. Smells.. Sour farmyard bret funk, some fruits & some wood. Tastes.. Fruity, maybe young green grapes is what I get, definitely tart and finished dry.
On tap @Chez Moeder Lambc Fontainas. Some sweet, sugary aromas. Pours dark gold, a bit amber, with nice white head. Light body, some crispy texture. Ends bitter. Quite enjoyable.

Cask at Moeder Lambic.

Faro is not really my style this wasnt the best ive had. Still very happy i got to try it.
Cask at Moeder Lambic, Brussels. Hazy orange colour with no head. Very little carbonation. Acidic, sour, caramel, sugar aroma. Flavour is sour, slightly sweet. Fruity acidic finish. Medium body.
Tap @ Moeder lambic. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are sweet malt, sugar, barnyard, funk, yeast and hops. Sour and sugary, but not too sweet.

On tap at Cantillon

Trying a faro on draft gives me a different perspective on this elusive style. ts not something I would choose to drink all the time. However it does let you do a side by side comparison with the "before" and "after" effects of aging (plus a generous helping of sugar).

Aroma / Appearance - The caramel bronze base retains no head and hardly any carbonation. Oaky sweet candy bars rise in the air like the tasting room of a sweet shop. The sourness is present but at this point very muted.

Flavor / Palate - Malted iced tea with a scoop of pure sugar remind me of Southern iced tea. This is almost as cloying as a Lindemans "lambic" minus the fruity aspects. One sample was enough for me before moving on to some of the finished products.

Cask at Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Light hazy amber/copper liquid with medium white head. Aroma of lemon, barnyard, white pepper, apples and raw sugar. Taste is light sweet and light sour with notes of lemon, raw sugar and apples. Medium bodied with low carbonation. Very drinkable and good tasting.
From mug at the brewery. Pours clear brown, no head. Aroma is malt, wheat, hint of caramel. Flavor is caramel, malt, sugar.

Glass @ Cantillon from a pitcher. Light amber color slightly hazy, served still with no head. Aroma is herbal tea and sugar, very little funk. Served from traditional lambic mug @ Cantillon, Brussels. :-) Pours a clear deep orange-amber body, which is quite still and with no head retention. (draught) pours a hazy deep amber colour with no head. aroma of caramel, vinegar, lemons and raisins, with a hint of vanilla and acetone. flavour is mostly caramel and vanilla, with a heavy initial sweetness and quite a bitter herbal-hoppy finish. medium-bodied with no carbonation.

Finally got to taste this - a must-have that I didnt expect too much from. Cloudy orange with a small white head. Aroma of wood, sugar, fruit and funk. Sweet, wooden/fruity flavour with notes of green leaves, and a tannin bitterness. Very unique, actually not as lambik-like character as some of the sweeter faros.

On tap at Moeder Lambic Fontainas,  pours a cloudy golden with a medium white head. Aroma of citric notes, moderate funk, and citrus zest -- no hint of sweetness. Flavour brings out a combination of sweet and citric sour notes, with citrus zest, and a little funk. Very citric and zesty, with the right addition of sugar. Awesome faro -- probably the best faro Ive had.
On tap at moeder lambic, brussels. Orange amber color. Gets hazy with high. Head is medium to high. High sourness and bitterness. Aroma is fruity, raisins and citrus.
UPDATED: NOV 9, 2013 Draft @ Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Amber with a lot of creamy foam. This is a good faro. Sour and sweet (candy sugar) but not too sweet like many other faros. Very fruity.

Draught @ Moeder Lambic Fontainas, Brussels. Rated on 27.2.2013.
Pours a hazy, murky golden colour with a large foamy head. Aroma of cough drops, licorice and citrus. Flavour of sweet syrup, cough drops, pungent citrusy notes, caramel and wood. Light bodied, slick mouthfeel and a sweet, slightly tangy finish. Surprisingly good for a faro.

Draft at moeder lambic. Faros are obviously not my thing. Im sure this is extremely well made but I couldnt drink it. Baby vomit, bile, sweet vandi sugar. Absolutely love every other beer made by cantillon but this is a tough one to swallow
UPDATED: OCT 2, 2013 Hazy amber color. Malt caramel and fruity aroma. Sweet, so sweet and light sour with fruity flavour.

From the cask at Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Darker than the lambic, more browny orange, hazy and big head. Basically tastes like lambic with a whole load of sugar dropped in (err wonder why?). Now I drink tea and coffee without sugar and dont like them with any sugar in so I wasnt going to like this really was I? Obviously becomes more approachable and less austere but somehow the sugar feels like its in precipitation and doesnt blend with the beer. Stick to the unsweetened stuff.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2015 Alla spina. Giallo paglierino intenso con sottile velo di schiuma bianca. Aroma pungente e dolciastro, sentori di lievito, malto, agrumi e fieno; gusto dolciastro, note di zucchero di canna che bilanciano lacidità tipica della Gueuze. On tap at Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas (Brussels, Belgium)
Aroma: Brown sugar, barnyard, citrus, and floral aromas.
Appearance: A light, slightly hazy amber color, with a small white head.
Taste: Sickly sweet. Like overly ripe fruit, with a bit of a tart finish. Not sure how it compares to other Faros, but nevertheless it was too sweet for me.
Palate: Medium bodied, thin, with a soft carbonation.
This is the first Faro that Ive tried. I knew beforehand what to expect, and unfortunately didnt find the style very likable in the end. I imagine Cantillons Faro would be one of the better Faros, but alas, it will be a while before I brave another one.

at Chez moeder lamiek fontainas, draft. 
had a head , yet no ( almosqt no ? ) carbonation.. weird.. 
not much on the nose. taste is typical cantillon - geuze thing, sweeter yet not apple-ish like i had with other faros. good, but not the best. one of the better ones so if you have the chance, drink this !

On tap at the brewery. It pours a golden colour with a small head. Quickly vanishing bubbles. Its slightly sweet and fruity with a slightly sour undertone and a hint of bitterness. Light to medium bodied, crisp and dry. Faro is my least favourite style of lambic, for sure.

Bottle pour at Cantillon Brewery, Brussels - 01/12/12.
Lightly hazed amber, no head.
Nose is sour, wood, musty, grandads shed, sweet sugars, light fruit.
Taste comprises much of the same qualities, burnt sugar/caramel, wood tones, sweet and soured lemon.
Smooth on the palate.
Most refreshing in a puckering way!

text: (From notes 18.11.12) Cask. It is as I remembered it. Considering how I perceive other Cantillons are very sour and dry, this is almost too sweet. Sugary sweetness battling the sourness. Pretty good though!

Bevuta alla spina alla moeder lambic, provata perchè di faro non ne avevo mai bevute prima. non ho trovato ciò che mi aspettavo, o meglio, sapevo dellapporto di zucchero e della limitata acidità, ma questo squilibrio verso il lato dolce non me lha fatta apprezzare del tutto. al naso è un pochino anonima, maltata, in bocca invece è più interessante, troppo dolce come dicevo, ma comunque ha quel tocco di complessità abbinato alla moderatissima acidità.

On cask at Moeder Lambic Fontainas.

The beer is light copper hued with a half inch of head. The aroma is funky and smells like cantillon, with the addition of some sweet, fruity tones. These scents carry over into the flavor. Sweet, but not cloying, with tartness and funk playing supporting roles.  Light bodied and fizzy on the palate, with lingering sweetness, reminiscent of a soda. Im not a huge fan of faros, but this is likely the best I have had in the style.

Enjoyed on the premises, after the brewery tour. Not being much of a Faro expert, I can still say with some confidence that this is the finest Ive tried. Murky reddish-brown pour, only a faint hint of carbonation, but thats perfectly fine. Wet oak, musk, with mild fruits and sugars in the nose. Mildly acidic mouthfeel, and slightly more tartness to taste. Traditional Faro sweetness is there but comparably understated given the tartness elsewhere present. Enjoyed it.

A flat amber pour with no head. Fairly sweet and sugary. Some light tartness remains underneath with a bit of sweet fruit. A touch bland considering the base beer. The flavor is not much different. Sweetness from the sugar is noticeable with only a mild sourness in the background. Some fruit/berry notes, a bit of grass, and mild mustiness.

At Cantillon Quintessence. Start of the day with this one, would be strange to end with a faro ... .
This is actually one of the best faros Ive ever drank. Citric sweet character, but not too sweet. Guess the sugar is very well fermented. Although not my style, this faro is pretty nice.
2012.10.06 - sample at brewery (brouwkwintessens Cantillon) - last sample (will re-evaluate this one later on)

Taster at brewery. Darker honey brown, a couple of bubbles. Sweet cidery aroma. Funky brown sugar, very still wort, some warming spices. Very juicy and still, cinnamon, light molasses. juicy funk, moldy in a nice way

On tap at the brewery. Has a hazy amber colour with some carbonation. Sweet aromas of roasted almonds with the sour lamibc in the background, and some caramel and brown sugar. Very sweet flavours as well and feels like a juice, and is fruity. It reminds me of ice tea actually. Sour lambic in the end and some spices. Pretty flat and slick mouthfeel, and minimal bitter. A fantastic experience of a lambic; really one of a kind.

(Draught at Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas, Brussels, 21 July 2012) Dark amber colour with frothy, off-white head. Fruity, acidic nose with notes of caramel, citrus and red berries. Fruity, tart taste with red fruit, citrus, hints of caramel and a touch of brown sugar in the finish. Medium body, with a certain sweetness. Faro has never really been my thing, but this was quite nice.

Cask @ Moeder Lambic Fontainas. The appearance is deep chestnut amber with a massive white head. The nose is concentrated sugary sweetness, some light pancake syrup. Mellow and inviting. The taste is simple sugar, lemon, lactic acidity. Light and drinkable. Soft. Not overly complex, but really pleasant and refreshing. Very nice!

Tap @ Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Hazy orange with a lasting off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, barnyard and dark sugar. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate acidic. Sweet and light acidic finish. Very refreshing. 170712

Cask @ Moeder Lambic Fontainas. A bit hazy, dark orange appearance with a fluffy white head. Dark fruity (raspberry, boysenberry), fairly sweet, spritzy lemon soda, light wood, somewhat herbal, mildly tart aroma. Earthy, sweet dark berry/raspberry, a touch syrupy, soda-like flavor. Not overly complex but smooth drinking. Aftertaste dissipates pretty quickly.

Tap @ Modern Lambic, Brussels. Pours cloudy amber with a creamy beigish head leaving small lacing. Aroma is sour dry grassy woody and fruuty. Flavor is sour astringent sweet bitter fruity but yet dry. Finishes dry bitter fruity and astringent.

Glass poured from the little brown barrel at Cantillon. Pours cloudy red with no head at all and a tannic aroma. There is a sweet fruity and candi sugar flavor with a tart finish. A truly traditional faro.

From the little brown plastic barrel (growler they took to go) at Moeder Lambic (Fontainas)

My wife got this one evening, I got it the next. hers was pretty much flat, mine had a small tight well retained head. The color is a kind of orange. 

The aroma is funky and lemony with a mild bit of livestock barn & some sweetness.

The flavor is very lemony, but also earthy and the sugar seems to be of a sort of brown varietal. This is not overly sweet but does the sweet and sour balancing act about as well as any other Faro I had in Belgium. At no point did it seem cloying or oversweet and it allowed for the earthiness of the lambic to play in as much as the sugar.

At the brewery - Burnt sugar, brown and bright. A mild and butterscotchy sweet nose. Sweet and cane-sugary in the mouth. Rich and sweet while still and slick. Very interesting.
Brown coloured. It smells mild-citrus. It tastes bitter-sweet, kandissugar. Not my taste 8/8/8/7/-/8

On draught at Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Pours a dark golden - amber colour with a thick white head. Aroma of musty yeast, horse blanket, candy sugar, caramel and alcohol. On tap at Moeder Lambic, Brussels. Looks amber, zero head, but tastes like white wine. Sour, bitter, a little funk. Enjoyed but probably wouldn't seek it out.

draft at Moeder Fountains... never been a big faro fan, and this didnt do much to change it, sweet hay, decent

Clear reddish/brownish with no head. The aroma was sweet with toffee, brown sugar, earth and some lemon. The taste was also sweet and rather strange to begin with. (I am not that used to drink a Faro) Then it became better. Toffee, sugar, some earth, funk and light berries. No carbonation. Very easy to drink. It was an interesting beer to try. (only 2 EUR for a glass)

Cask at Moeder Lambic.  Pours deep amber with no head at all.  Flat as can be.  Smells like pear juice.  Flavor is sweet with just a hint of sour.  Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy.  After a talk with the brewers at Cantillon about this beer, I realize that it is a bit of a gimic.  Not really impressed and wont be searching for any more Faro again.

cask @ moeder lambic.  Sweet sugar with funk on the nose.  Pours amber with a thin white head.  Sweet upfront with acidity sneaking in right away with sweet lemon in the finish with traces of brown sugar.

Cask at Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Brown orange hazy amber colour with massive beige bubbly head. Aroma is sugar sweetness with a bit of funk. Quite grainy and some wood. Taste is sweet and vinous, maybe even a touch of creaminess at times. Bit appley too and just a hint of citrus sourness.

Casks at Moelder Lambic Fontainas.
Cloudy amber appearance with a froathy white head that stays on the surface till the end... Nice aroma of a real Cantillon brewed Lambic, light grapes and vinous tartness, green leaves and dried peach. Easy character of a Lambic with the added sugars. Sourish tarty taste, light barnyard balanced with a fine sweetness, green leaves. Interesting. Exciting!

Had this at Chez Moeder Lambic, Fontinas Pl location, Brussels, Belgium 16.12.11   Pours light amber with a white head. The aroma reminds me of walking into an old charity shop, there is old clothes and dog eared books and records, this is the most interesting thing about the beer, the aroma is fascinating. However the taste is frankly something of a disappointment, it is sweet, thin and rather watery. I tried to have this at the brewery a few years ago but was repeatedly steered away from it and told by Jean Roy (I think) that I shouldnt try that I need to have the proper stuff, despite repeated requests I seriously wasnt allowed, instead given some of the proper stuff Im beginning to think that when offered up against many of the other Cantillon beers his advice was spot on. To be honest Ill probably be frowned at for saying this but I preferred the Timmermans Lambic Doux which rather surprises me.  A7 A4 T5 P3 Ov12  3.1

Tap, Moeder Lambic.  Pours a slightly cloudy amber body with a fizzy and frothy white head.  Certainly sugary on the nose, but much more delicate than other Faros Ive had.  More of the cellar/cobweb funk of a real Lambic.  Very drinkable, great balance on the sweetness.  Still funky as hell but sweet up front.  Dries out a lot on the finish with a slight mineral note.  Mouthfeel is rather light and airy with perfect soft fizzy carbonation.  Long lingering funky finish.  Best Faro Ive had yet.

I got this on tap from cantillon when they had there open brewday.
This is by far the best Faro i ever tasted, the ballance of the sour lambic with the cadnico (dark brown) sucre is excelant ! Not a complex beer, but really nice. Would definaitly wanna drink this again !

Poured up at Cantillon with clear deep gold to copper body and almost no head at all. The aroma is a big and yummy kiss of bread, musty funkiness and then a wide variety of fruity goodness. These notes are going together wonderfully with fruit like peach, apricot and plum. The taste is right there too starting with a pleasing fresh bready type grainy wort with a smooth yeasty tartness and plenty of fruit like peaches, apricots, plums and a bit of sugary sweet mango. Man this one is fresh, crisp, complex and refreshing. Love it. The fruit, yeasty tartness and graininess play so well together. It is very tempting to skip everything else planned today and tip more and more of this stuff back until they close.

On tap at Moeder Lambic Fonteinas. It poured a foggy golden liquid with an orange tint. Smell of earth cellar, fruity and sour. Sweet taste of fruits, sugar, farmhouse and horse blanket. Incredibly easy to drink, like velvet on my throat.
Very nice. Hardly any sweetness to it. Leaves lots of lambic. Flat and smooth.

20 cl sample from plastic keg @ the brewery. Rated on 19.07.2010
Aroma is very sweet with brown sugar and syrup. Flavour is very, very sweet and syrupy with brown sugar. Also some distant earthy notes in the background. Very sticky palate that can be observed also on the edge of the glass. This could work as a very small amount after dinner.

@ Stone fest , Chez moeder lambic 
Head: creamy, white, thick 
Colour: amber/brown

light sour aroma,golden, hazy, white foam, lightly sour, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, nice soft sour finish.

Draft at Moeder Lambic. Light brown coloured and hazy. Has an off-white head, fully lasting. Aroma of herbs, heavy yeasty, barnyard, perhaps leather, acid. Bevuta in cask al Moeder Lambic Fontainas, Bruxelles; prima esperienza con un Faro, contrasto notevole tra dolce e acido

Served in a Cantillon big-bowled wine glass, poured from a jug.

The nose is slightly cidery with some earthy must. Maybe must more than cider. A bit of funk. Light sweetness comes in during the taste. Light body with a faint bit of sugar and mild funk. No real acidity. Nice enough to try, but Id much rather have the young lambic without the sugar.
Draught at Chez Moeder Lambic Saint Gilles, Brussels, Belgium august 2011. Dark orange, almost clear, no head. Dough aroma. Sweet, fruity..maybe a bit pumpkin aroma. Nice, exsiting taste.
Tap at moeder lambic. Pours a golden colour. Taste is pretty lively it has a nice tarty ness to it. The beer has a good after taste and a good finish. good offering
Draught at Chez Moeder Lambic Saint Gilles, Brussels. Orange beer. no head. Yeasty aroma, sweetish with some dough. Vinous sourish flavor, a bit sweet, elder notes, pumpkin, maybe some plums.
On cask.  A nice reddish brown color with very light to no head.  Earthy and sweet.  Smooth and drinkable.

Freshly mixed at the brewery for my 3,000th rating. Glowing bronze-brown color, flat. Nose of caramel, brown sugar, funk, underlying lemon. Flavors of lemon, brown sugar, dary, dusty funk, caramel. Not too sweet at all. Lovwely lemon flavors. Rich and flat body, slightly oily. Somewhat reminiscent of lemon iced tea. Great.

Red and nut brown, no head, translucent. Nose is earthy with light rind, sugar, and citrus. Flavor more cobeweb, sugar, caramel, mint, and light sweetness leading through the finish. Nice balance, well-carbonated, but the sugar is excessive and a bit muting.

Poured from the 5l takeaway barrel that was brought home. Dark, flat pour with no head. Dark meaning a dark brown like a lightened, diluted molasses. Smells like a jonge lambic, not surprising since it was a jonge lambic they put sugar into. Tastes sweet and acidic with some tartness and the sourness associated with the typical lambic. Nice, sweetened version for people who do not like the full on lambic twang.
Cask pour at moeder lambic. Brownish pour with tan head, very hazy. Nutty, light tartness, woodiness added sweetness, fruit comes through a bit more than the unsweetened lambic.

Künstlich süßer Antrunk, zum Glück stellt dies den süßesten Teil dar. Das Faro wird milder und schmeckt deutlich holzig, leider weiterhin auch etwas künstlich. Der Nachgeschmack geht in Orndund, immerhin ist hier auch mal eine leichte Säuerlichkeit zu erkennen.

tap at moeder lambic.  blended half and half with the jonge lambic.    pours dark orange with dark tan highlights.    half inch offwhite head.  peculiar aroma of passion fruit, grassy, herbal lemons, kiwi fruit, melons, and a touch of earthy basement.  uniquie, tasty beer.    would have guessed this was made with some tropical fruits, tangerines, or banananas.  pretty good.

Cask @ Moeder Lambic Fontainas, Brussels.
Pours hazy amber with a nice, frothy, off-white head. Aroma has clear sugar, light caramel, mild tartness. Almost no carbonation, fat oily and fairly dry mouthfeel. Bottle:

text: On tap at Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas. It pours light hazy amber, with a tiny bubbly off-white head and no carbonation. The nose is sweet apple, toffee, lemon ice tea, pine and melon. The taste is lemon ice tea, melon, wood, sweet lime, sweet orange, caramel and grass. This is way too sweet and tastes too much like iced tea for my liking. Faro is not for me.

Caramel colour, no carbonation, no head. Aroma mainly sweet. Only slight lambic character. Light brett, light caramel. The sweetness seems to overpower all other aromas. Flavour mainly sweet, caramel, quite cloying. Aftertaste lingering sour and dry, bit astringent.

But then again, I never had the Cantillon faro before, so Im happy Ive tried it. Not bad, but didnt quite finish the glass as I liked the others of the day more.
(Served from ceramic jug @ the brewery, 27 May 2011, Brussels)
From a jug in the brewery.  Golden brown pour with no head.  Slightly sweet, slightly yeasty aroma.  Sweet flavor withthe usual sourness after.

From the cask at Cantillon
Copper amber color with no head. 
The aroma is a mixture of a slight sweetness but definetely a great sourness, the tartness is quite far away. The flavor repeats the aroma but has like most Cantillon a lemon like sour touch to it which makes it very refreshing. Dry finish. 
Decentfaro but less sweet then you normaly expect from a faro.

My first authentic faro. Dark unclear amber with a large but dissipating head. Sweet aroma, a little on the mild side, sugar, slight funk and no sourness. The flavour is very sweet without being cloying, some funk, orange and peach also. The palate is quite light.
Ottima, amara ma con moderazione e non eccessivamente aspra. Buon corpo, note di legno e resina, con finale secco.

M: Medium bodied. Decent amount of carbonation and zip considering this was on cask.

O: Of the few faros out there, this is one of the better ones.

On tap at Chez Moeder Lambik Brussels. Looks good in the glass, deep golden, modest turbid, nice head. Starts quite sweet, mild, then more and more sourish, a bit moldy. Long lasting finish, still moldy, modest sweet. Very well balanced. Nice!
Compared to their other beers - this one is very mellow.  Pours yellow with a small off white head.  Mellow aroma and slightly sweet flavor - this is a very easy beer to drink. Well done.
Fresh at the brewery.  Delicious and smooth, but a bit overly sweet compared to the other samples that afternoon.  Still a delightful beer and worth drinking again.

Draft at Moeder Lambic.  Slightly cloudy yellow amber pour, small bubbly off-white head.  Fruit, leather, lots of sugary sweetness, slight sourness in the background.  I am not that impressed, but then I again I really dislike sweetened beers.

One of the most beautiful Lambic experiences. Something sensational. I had it at Cantillon Brewery and at Moeder Lambic Fontainas. It is extremely particular thanks to the addition of rock candy. A great balancing between the sharp and sweet. An intense play of flavours giving us a special sensation. Absolutely to try whenever is possible. Served directly from the jug.

[3317-20100809] Plastic keg. Caramel toast aroma has strong un-fermented wort and light toasted grapes. Hazy, dark brown body with quick off-white bubbles. More like wort or fermenting apples in the flavour, with just some notes of sweet caramel. Medium-full body has a sour background. Not my favourite style but it grows on you after several sips.
(@ brewery, Brussels, Belgium)

Cantillon faro. Draft at Chez Moeder Lambic Fonteinas... First faro . Pours a  
reddish plum brown hue, mostly opaque, with a huge fluffy soapy white  
head... Aroma of sweet sugar confection and a berry plumminess to  
coincide with it...Flavors have a plummy berry presence, semi-tart  
through the beginning and middle and finishes on a sweeter bent but  
not a total suger bomb like I was expecting. Body is soft as is the  
carbonation. A little sweet for my liking but thats what I was coming  
to expect from a faro.
7/4/7/4/14
Pitcher @ the brewery. Pours dark orange. Aroma of candy sugars, caramel, caramel cloying the mouth. Not much going on because of the flatness.

On tap in Brussels at Moerder Lambic. The aroma is of burnt brown sugar, very potent. The dark caramel color has a creamy cappuccino head on top. There are big sweet notes in the flavor, that unlike of Cantillon! The notes probably come from the sugar and caramel added which are very potent on the palate, especially in the beginning. Then the noticeable tart flavor characteristic of Cantillon comes at the end and settles smoothly.

On draft at Moeder Lambic. Pours a dark copper almost brown color with a huge white head. On draft. The aroma is sweet sugars and fruit, some dry yeast. Unlike other Faros, a strong fruity lambic base only added to with sugars. Quite natural and earthy. Wonderful. I had two glasses.

It took a second visit to Belgium to finally get to sample Cantillons faro, I had it cask conditioned at Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Pours a cloudy amber color with a medium, bubbly, beige head. Nice aroma of white wine, acidity, mild funk and candi sugar. Very good flavor of candi sugar with some acidity to balance the sweetness, theres also some funk and a lactic presence. The body is light with a creamy texture and soft carbonation. Its definitely the best Faro Ive had so far.

Has a nice subtle aroma, no hint of artificial sweetness. Appearance is a perfect dark amber colour, and brilliant head. Taste is lambic but sweet, caramel notes, and a dark syrup finish. Well blended, all articulate flavours, none lost. The folks at Cantillon get it right, yet again.

Rich mahogany pour with a creamy, frothy head. Aroma holds lots of cane sugar, a touch of plum, fig, and raisin, and a light tartness- really interesting nose to this brew. Flavor is far darker than expected, with increased dark fruit, candied sugars, and something that reminded me of the best Sour Patch Kids ever created, without the aggressive aftertaste. No carbonation, but a silky smooth mouthfeel. Really impressive stuff.

Lambic and candi sugar, what could possibly go wrong?

Irish whiskey with cream on top is what it looks like. Caramel and molasses is how it tastes. It finishes dry for the amount of sugar. And it has much sugar.

As Ive had just one other Faro, I dont have much to compare this to. This is easier to drink than Boons, hence the 3.5 ratings, but thats not much of a recommendation.
user_location: The Court of the Crimson King, California, USA

text: 7th March 2010. Draft at Moeder Lambic. Cloudy brown beer, thick frothy off white head. Milky sweet beer - very sweet. Sweet prunes and figs and plums and then more milky sweetness. Just a little tartness in the background but its swamped by the sweetness. All this is good but then there is some off putting paint in there as well and this just makes things a little too weird to score any higher.

25cl draft @ Moeder Lambic, Brussels.
pours hazy copper, off-white head.
aroma, nice wooden nose with outstanding sweetness and mild notes of residual sugars.
flavors, a lot more true to style, not sure how you can possibly bottle a faro - some fruit elements, and this one keeps a sugary approach while at the same time keeping a mild tart - wood aspect. Carbonation is close to zero.
Some floating sediments to be noted.
This is tasty, regardless of what many argue pointlessly about Faros not being deserving.

In short: Euhhh A very sweet (candy-ish) unblended lambic.  Duh
How: Hand-pumped at Moeder Lambic Fontainas, Brussels Belgium
The look: Clear amber body topped by a large bubbly off-white head with good retention
In long: Nose is a mix of candy and barnyard.  Body is juicy and carbonation is very soft.  Taste is liquid candy, a tiny bit of funk, some caramel, red apples.  Sweetness comes out strong and makes the beer feel a bit syrupy.  Nothing special here.  I much preferred the 3 Fonteinen Faro.  Im not sure I see the point of Faros anyway.  Sweetening lambics should be a criminal offence, punishable by flagellation, plus surgery to enlarge the ears.

On draft at Moeder Lambic. Dark amber with very low carbonation. Aromas are of sour apple skin, wood, and brown sugar. Wood and apple flavors dominate wtih a tart lemon and sweet sugar finish. Unusual, but the sweetness is low (and balanced) enough that it keeps things refreshing. Good stuff.

Draught at Moeder Lambic and at from a jug at Cantillon Brewery, Sept 2009. Pours golden amber, topped with a thin tan head. Mildly sweet candi sugar aroma, tempering but not elimination the lactic acid tartness. Flavor retains some of the tartness, but sugar definitely is the primary flavor. There is a slight herbal character in the background as well. Better balance of sweet and sour than most other faros; not as heavy-handed with the sugar.

aroma is sweet white grape juice--almost candy--and oak.
it pours a thick and cloudy dark orange with no head.
flavor is again grape juice, with a sticky sweetness but not much other flavor and an odd bitter finish -- imagine drinking grape juice after brushing your teeth.
thin-bodied but somehow syrupy and, again, flat.
i dont know, not a huge fan of this, it felt watered down and just odd.

Draught at Moeder Lambic Fontainas, Brussels. Murky amber with dense frothy white head. Sweet nose and taste of apricot, peach, leather, caramel and candy sugar. Soft and rounded mouthfeel. A touch of sweetness in the finish. A good introduction to the style.

On cask at Cantillon during open brewing session. Poured a deep caramel amber with a very nice tan head. Aroma of caramel, sugar, and some lambic funk. Taste is toffee, raisins, brown sugar plus a fantastic unblended lambic base. Really nice sweet and sour mix. Moves to medium body from the edition of the sugars/caramel.

Fresh light fruity citrus aroma.  A light brown-amber color with a nice tan head.  Moderate citrus-grapefruit flavors with a dryness.  A good gateway-lambic due to the sweetness.

Notes:  March 2010 on visit to Cantillon for Public Brewing Session

In a bar in Bruessels. Color is yellow/white. Aroma of funk and candy. Flavor of sugar with hints of funk. No carbonation. Overall more interesting than tasty however I think its hard to do a better Faro.

Dirrect from the hand tab at Cantillon since they say it cannot be bottled. Color is hazy brown with and nice off white head that stay a long time.  Aroma is of malts and caramels.  Flavors of malts and mostly of very natural fresh sugar cane, almost like there drinking sugar cane juice itself.  With a little sweet and refreshing finish.  This was very different and very pleasant.

After the beer was served in the glass there was found a lasting quantity not wall adhesive light brown foam collar which was fine and evenly of structure. The beer also contained no carbonic acid in the glass. 

The beer has a clear brown color and a sweet taste. The after tast of the beer is light hoppy bitter with a candy touch. This beer smells to candy.

From the jug at Cantillon, 17 months lambic with brown sugar. Aroma is a mix of caramel almost brown ale like malt, with a good malt vinigar acidity. Taste is great, the cantillon goodness mixed with the brown sugar sweetness is on the sweet side of balanced but is light and delicate enough to make it a fabolous drink. This was a good change to the 6 pints or so of straight lambic id already had that day.

Had on draft at Moeder Lambic in Brussels, a night before heading to the Cantillon brewery for another sample of it. The beer was poured from a little plastic jug that looked like a wooden barrel. 

The beer poured a light golden color with just a few bubbles around the edge, no carbonation but that is to be expected with how the beer was served and the style. The aroma was sweet, not really candy sweet but borderline. Not as sweet as other Faros in Belgium. The taste was sweet up front but there was some of the trademark Cantillon tartness that balanced this beer out very well. Although not my favorite lambic style but I find it very interesting and everytime I can find one, I go after it.

Sample at brewery and at Moeder Lambic. Hazy yellow peach colored. Arome is fruit, sugar, tart and acidic. Lots of sugar but not too sweet. Taste is funky lambic with sugar. Some tart not much. It is sweet but far from being a sugar bomb. Quite drinkable. It is different and very enjoyable.

Blended at Moeder Lambic. deep amber, almost copper, hazy with just a few bubbles on top. Sharp acidic lemony lambik aromas mellowed by sugar. Toffee, raisins and lemon flavours, with a mild, but dry finish. Body is light as expected. A wonderful blend.

(Draught)  Pours a lightly hazy orange body with a spare quickly dissipating white head.  Aroma of candi sugar, white grape, light scotch, and earthiness.  Flavor of earthy hops, candi sugar, and wood with a dry, mildly bitter finish.

Tap @ Moeder Lambic.  Pours hazy orange and still.  Aroma is sweet and sour, maybe grapy.  Taste starts sugar sweet with some sourness trying to peek out.  More caramel later on.  Some acetone abrasiveness.  Better than Girardin by some margin.

draft at Chez Moeder Lambic in Brussels - Pours lightly hazy orange with no head.  It smells funky, malty, and earthy.  The taste is of mildly sweet malt and candi sugar with notes of earth and funk.  The sugar is lighter than other faros I tried.  The mouthfeel was oddly flat though.  Is it supposed to be almost uncarbonated?  That was disappointing for what was otherwise a very enjoyable session beer.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2009 At Cantillon, Brussels, Belgium.
Taster from the brewer
Golden with no head. Aroma and flavor is sweet with toast and caramel.
Draught at brewery & moeder lambic. Muddy golden/amber with small bubbles on top. Sweet, dry leather aroma. Dusty sweet taste with notes of caramel, sugar & bread. Very nice Faro.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2010 On draught.  Dark amber color.  Sweet and sour taste in a nice balance, with citrus overtones. 3.8
Second sample, on tap at Cantillon public brewing day 2010.  Reddish brown color, coca cola head, same sweet/sour taste, more apple flavor.  3.9.

From a jug at the brewery. Pours with no carbonation and no head. Dark orange coloured. Diacetyl aroma and malty/grainy, not pleasant. Butterish and malty flavoured. Ends flat and light sweet with a persisting butterish note. I was warned that this was for people that don’t really like gueuzes and lambics :) and questioned several times if I REALLY wanted this.

Draught @ Chez Moeder Lambic, Brussels 1060, Belgium.Unclear medium amber color with a virtually none appearance, virtually none lancing, head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, wheat, brown sugar, candy sugar, barnyard. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat to soft. (250508)

Aroma:  some honey, minerals, mustiness/earthiness, carmel

Appearance:  reddish-brown, little to no head

Flavor:  raw grains of sugar, candy sugar, lite tartness, some summer fruits--like cherry and cherry stems, light honey

Palate:  fruity tartness and sweetness, nice raw sugar aftertaste followed by a slight lacticness

Cask/ceramic jug at Chez Moeder in Brussels.  Still, slightly hazy dark copper color - no head.  Sweet brown sugar and Belgian candy sugar in the nose and flavor, but surprisingly it has some nice acidity - wet, oily, medium-to-full body, with sweet apple cider and some light funk and acidity, very raw sort of flavor, very real for faro.  Weedy and smooth in the finish, nice overall.

Pours a headless orange-amber color.  Aroma is burnt sugar cane sweetness.  Not much there to separate this from other common faros.  Taste reduces that nasty sweetness. Its still there but the base beer is felt in a slight wild/barnyard flavor breaking through the muck creating a nice drinkable sweet mild lambic.  The flavor really grew on me as I kept at it and it became more drying as I kept drinking.  By the end a good amount of tartness began to be felt at the end of the flavor. By this point this was the best faro I had had.Cask @ Cantillon Brewery, poured out of a faro ceramic jug, on 5/17/08.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: (Poured from jug at the brewery on 2008-03-22) Orange colour. Hazy. Sweet nose. Sugary taste lacking almost completly the normal lambic sourness. But some sourness remains. Good.
From a plastic jug at the brewery. Hazy orange colour with a very thin head. Sweet sugary aroma and taste with some sour notes. A faro on the sweet side.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2011 Re-rate 9/7/09: Tap sample at the brewery in Brussels. Deep reddish brown color. Aroma of brown sugar, some demerara is in there as well, and some funky, slightly vinegar-like, acidity. Sweet sugary flavor (candy-like) with a very faded sourness and a bit of barnyard tones. Finishes a bit drier. Medium-bodied. Too restrained but decent. 7/4/6/3/14=3.4
<BR[3/12/08] On tap at Chez Moeder Lambic in Brussels. Hazy dark orange with no head. Aroma of citrus, some barnyard and candy sugar. Sweetish sugary flavor with sour touches of citrus and some brett. Medium-bodied. Quite good. 7/4/7/3/14=3.5
From a plastic jug at "Chez Moeder Lambic". Cloudy red/amber - white edges. Grape, candy sugar, light sourness, nice medium sweetness, light vinegrapes, light berries. OK !!!

(At the brewery) On March 22, 2008. Slight shady golden color, small white head. A bit wood, floral, acidic smooth scent. Sweet, citrus, acidic taste. A bit lactic and metallic aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel, low bitterness.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2010 2010-08-09. Lightly hazy, mahogany brown body, headless. 3+ Unexpectedly sweet, almost molasses like, or unfermented wort. 6+ Flavour is similar, sweet malty wort like character with mild acidic undertones, particularly in the finish. Smooth average palate is more full bodied than the lambics. Okay, but kind of terrible as it warms up. 6+/3+/6/3/12 - 3.0 Plastic Jug at Cantillon, Brussels
2008-03-05. Dark headless amber body is mostly still. Aroma is mild, hints at the juicy fruitiness of the flavour, overall it is a bit to subtle to dissect right now.  Flavour has an interesting fruit character, tangy apple juice, light sourness. Interestingly the sourness becomes the most sharp in the aftertaste and the finish. Lightly musty malts make occasional interjections. Fairly well balanced, it has few flavours that stick out but what is there is well blended and balanced. Juicy apples return, somewhat sweeter this time. Different somehow than the other faros that I have had on this trip,better blended, less of the musty lambic character. Surprisingly not sour for Cantillon! But of course as soon as I wrote that down I got a brief sharp lemon seed sour note that mellows quickly. (7+) The sourness seems to increase with the speed of consumption, particularly near the end of the glass. A slow sipper would this find it much milder than a faster drinker. Average palate is still, and suits the beer nicely. Greater carbonation might lighten the palate to its detriment. Rather nice even if it does not score particularly highly. 7/3/7/3/15 - 3.5 On tap at Chez Moeder Lambic, St. Gilles, Brussels

Bottle (Cantillon, Brussels)
Hazy orange, no head. Raw woody and sour aroma. Burnt sugar in the taste.  Sticky heavy sourness, slightly grapefruity bitterness, and a bitter sticky finish. My worst ever Cantillon, despite being in the best surroundings ever for drinking it. Just didnt have the lifting lightness that I expect from Cantillon, alas. A dour beer.
colore dorato carico note dolciastre zuccero candi in bocca leggermente dolciastro ma anche una buona acidità

Slightly hazy - mostly clear ruby tinted amber coloured body. Aroma of sour grapes, yeast, wheat and vinegar - great! Light-bodied; Nice sweet and sour flavour up front of grapes and yeast with malt following soon behind. Aftertaste shows great character - pretty sweet, sour, hoppy and even a bit spicey. Overall, great - where has this beer been in the US? I sampled this poured from a small jug at Chez Moeder Lambic in Bruxelles, Belgium on 28-December-2007.

[To mark my 200th rating - Draught at Chez Moeder Lambic] Hazy golden with no head. Sour aroma with barnyardy notes and grapefruit. Sweet and sour flavor with brett notes, grapefruit, grapes and sugar. Lovely!

Tasted at the brewery.  Beautiful deep golden-orange colour.  Aroma is fairly swet, soft pale caramel and a fruity apricot/grapefruit aroma.  Completely still.  The highly acidic notes are quite muted in the nose, but the classic house character still comes through.  Flavour is quite nice however, with a touch of acid present just at the sides of the mouth.  The sweetness dampens the acidity quite a bit though.  Quite sugary palate.  Flavour has lots of fruitiness, lemon and grapefruit with a soft pithy bitterness across the back.  Lingering brown sugar flavour.  Lightly leathery with an earthy barnyardy character.

Draught, Moeder Lambic. Flat cloudy orange. Cheesy, citrusy (grapefruit, orange tea) aroma. Quite interesting really. Accurate dosage. Apple cider undertones and clear wheat influence. Certainly sugary in mid-palate, but just a soft caramel that would fit any Belgian ale. Leafy finish. Excellent stuff.
Draught at Moeder Lambic.  Excellent faro, just got the right mix of sweet and sour.  Very pleasant.  Chardonnay grape like.  Vinous.

Faro is a unique beer-drinking experience. Had on tap at a special bar called Zageman in Brussels, the Cantillon faro is undoubtedly a benchmark for this style. Faro pours exceptionally flat. In fact, the beer is one of the flatter beers I have enjoyed. The alcohol content is so low it makes it easy to drink, and they are excellent summer heat or daytime drinking beers. The same is also true because the faro is relatively sweet. Very drinkable. The faro is served in a thick glass mug, quite unlike the delicate tulip glasses too. Cantillon faro makes a far different drinking experience in general from other lambic-based beers.
Sampled @ the brewery. Hazy golden in colour with a medium sized white head. Slightly acidy with notes of brett, citrus, wood and somewhat sweet and tart.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2007 Jug.  Yep, I drank this as poured out of a jug at the brewery.  I asked the brewer  if there was any Faro since it was listed on their chalkboard but not on the menu, and he said that he had just completed a batch the previous day and had some from his first sampling left that I could try.  Toffee-amber color, no head at all.  Aroma of fresh-cut vegetation, honey, apricot, nectarine.  Very "young" tasting and complex.  Honey, apples, grapes, and hazlenut in the wonderful flavor.  Cantillon Brewery rocks!

Draught at the brewery.
Cloudy golden coloured with a white ehad.
Fruity aroma with of brett and yeast with notes of wood.
Fruity flavour of brett and wood witj light acidic notes.
Tart finish.

Bottle @ Cantillon. We were told that this can only be keepet in bottles for 3 to 4 weeks else it will explode because of the caramel and sugar that has been added to the Lambic. No head and not lacing. Somewhat copper like colour. Aroma was quit sweet for something that originate from Lambic. Dusty dry notes are there with the caramel and sugar notes as well. Hint of fresh fruit and wood blends in as well. Medium bodied with a soft carbonation. Flavour was light acidic with sweet notes as well. Dry and light tart finish. Belgium 25-05-2007

I have this while drinking Belgium beers tour in Belgium.  At museum brewhouse is served.  Wow! Another sweet Belgium beer, but is not so sweet like sugar stout.  Sure it is like "gueuze" but I can drinking more of this because sugar helps remove sulfur and rubber taste that I am drinking in "gueuze".  I would drinking with trappist beers!
From the jug at the brewery. Cloudy bronze coloured. Very sweet, almost like a sticky dessert wine but balanced by lambic flavours with a caramel finish. Drinkable.

From a jug at the brewery. Cloudy yellow.
Sweet, peach-like fruit, but with the lambic sourness underneath. A bit too syrupy for me, more interesting than great.

Brownorange.
Elderberry aroma with notes of muscovado sugar. Some acid.
Elderberry flavour with notes of wort and icetea. Sweet.
For me Faro is a good way of ruining lambic !

Sampled at Cantillon on public brew day.  So this is probably one of the best faros to date.. but thats only because theres that insane Cantillon sourness beneath to balance out some of the sticky sweetness of the faro.. Much rather have the straight lambic.. faros always sems oily and cloying to me.

Draught at tSpinnekopke, Brussels. Gentle sourness, a little jam. Aromaof candied fruits and jelly sweets. Regulated mouthful - good balance of citric flavour, with a short finish. Very smooth, almost docile.

A Mes rate: Poured from a large ceramic jug at Cantillon. Totally flat, obviously. Great orange colour. Toffee and sugar is just about there but not as sweet as other faros. Guess Cantillon just find it really hard to bring themselves to produce something sweet. Most unusual syrup texture. Almost has the feel of drinking neat cordial. Good old Cantillon make sure there is a quick kick of sour at the finish followed by a truckload of caramel. Definitely a top faro.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2008 Sampled at brewery tour at Cantillion - Pours dark golden with no head. Aroma of sour grapes, cherries, and tart apples. Taste  is sweeter than the rest of the Cantillion offerings, some toffee, only slightly tart, and very similar to the young lambic. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, tart, and nearly flat.

Tried at the Cantillon brewery 27/05/06. Bright caramel body, Initial sugar hit then can slightly taste the caramel with the sugar. I liked this but much rather be drinking the Gueze which I thought was great.

t Spinnekopke, Brussel. Hazy dark brown with a thin bubbly head. Mushy, dusty and still fresh and fruity aroma with some dark candy(sweetened), some sulfur can be detected too. Tastes sweet, sourrish(not as acidic as other Cantillons), cobwebs, apple, dark candy and a bit band-aid(phenolic). Short sourrish finish. A bit sticky, full tasting, soft beer. Try it, if youre in Brussel.

Draught at Le Zageman. Orange brown body with a small white top. The nose is pretty good - solid punchy fruit funkiness and sticky sweet apricot and peaches along with a smooth butteriness. Doesnt seem nearly as scary as I anticipated a Faro to be though it is literally sticky from the sugar. Peach tartness to counteract but the sweetness cuts the acidity way too much for me to really enjoy this. Still quite good but I certainly dont have a  benchmark for the style. Im off to a good start though!

Pours with a golden body topped by a medium thick head with some lacing.  Its slightly sweet and fruity with a slightly sour undertone and a hint of bitterness.  Very nice.  Light to medium bodied, crisp and dry.

From small barral @ the brewery: Unclear golden coloured. Fluffy white head. Very sweet and fruity. Like many faros the smell and flavour reminds me of cold tee. Good cold tee though. Has a nice sweet touch and a touch of sourness lingering way back.
